lines.text: Enter KATHARINA and GRUMIO

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: No, no, forsooth I dare not for my life.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears: What, did he marry me to famish me Beggars, that come unto my fathers door, Upon entreaty have a present aims If not, elsewhere they meet with charity: But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oath kept waking and with brawling fed: And that which spites me more than all these wants, He does it under name of perfect love As who should say, if I should sleep or eat, Twere deadly sickness or else present death. I prithee go and get me some repast I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: What say you to a neats foot

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: I fear it is too choleric a meat. How say you to a fat tripe finely broild

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: I cannot tell I fear tis choleric. What say you to a piece of beef and mustard

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard, Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave, That feedst me with the very name of meat: Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you, That triumph thus upon my misery! Go, get thee gone, I say.
Beats him
Enter PETRUCHIO and HORTENSIO with meat

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: How fares my Kate What, sweeting, all amort

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Mistress, what cheer

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Faith, as cold as can be.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Pluck up thy spirits look cheerfully upon me. Here love thou seest how diligent I am To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks. What, not a word Nay, then thou lovest it not And all my pains is sorted to no proof. Here, take away this dish.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: I pray you, let it stand.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: The poorest service is repaid with thanks And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: I thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame. Come, mistress Kate, Ill bear you company.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: [Aside]  Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me. Much good do it unto thy gentle heart! Kate, eat apace: and now, my honey love, Will we return unto thy fathers house And revel it as bravely as the best, With silken coats and caps and golden rings, With ruffs and cuffs and fardingales and things With scarfs and fans and double change of bravery, With amber bracelets, beads and all this knavery. What, hast thou dined The tailor stays thy leisure, To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure. Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments Lay forth the gown. What news with you, sir
Enter Tailor
Enter Haberdasher

lines.speaker: haberdasher
lines.text: Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, this was moulded on a porringer A velvet dish: fie, fie! tis lewd and filthy: Why, tis a cockle or a walnutshell, A knack, a toy, a trick, a babys cap: Away with it! come, let me have a bigger.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Ill have no bigger: this doth fit the time, And gentlewomen wear such caps as these

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: [Aside]  That will not be in haste.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak And speak I will I am no child, no babe: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears. My tongue will tell the anger of my heart, Or else my heart concealing it will break, And rather than it shall, I will be free Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, thou sayst true it is a paltry cap, A custardcoffin, a bauble, a silken pie: I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Love me or love me not, I like the cap And it I will have, or I will have none.
Exit Haberdasher

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Thy gown why, ay: come, tailor, let us seet. O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here Whats this a sleeve tis like a demicannon: What, up and down, carved like an appletart Heres snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barbers shop: Why, what, i devils name, tailor, callst thou this

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: [Aside]  I see shes like to have neither cap nor gown.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Marry, and did but if you be rememberd, I did not bid you mar it to the time. Go, hop me over every kennel home, For you shall hop without my custom, sir: Ill none of it: hence! make your best of it.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: I never saw a betterfashiond gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable: Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, true he means to make a puppet of thee.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble, Thou yard, threequarters, halfyard, quarter, nail! Thou flea, thou nit, thou wintercricket thou! Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant Or I shall so bemete thee with thy yard As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest! I tell thee, I, that thou hast marrd her gown.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: Your worship is deceived the gown is made Just as my master had direction: Grumio gave order how it should be done.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: I gave him no order I gave him the stuff.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: But how did you desire it should be made

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: But did you not request to have it cut

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Thou hast faced many things.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: I have.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Face not me: thou hast braved many men brave not me I will neither be faced nor braved. I say unto thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown but I did not bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou liest.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Read it.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: The note lies ins throat, if he say I said so.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: [Reads]  Imprimis, a loosebodied gown:

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Master, if ever I said loosebodied gown, sew me in the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom of brown thread: I said a gown.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Proceed.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: [Reads]  With a small compassed cape:

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: I confess the cape.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: [Reads]  With a trunk sleeve:

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: I confess two sleeves.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: [Reads]  The sleeves curiously cut.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Ay, theres the villany.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Error i the bill, sir error i the bill. I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again and that Ill prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

lines.speaker: tailor
lines.text: This is true that I say: an I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: I am for thee straight: take thou the bill, give me thy meteyard, and spare not me.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Godamercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: You are i the right, sir: tis for my mistress.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Go, take it up unto thy masters use.

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress gown for thy masters use!

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, sir, whats your conceit in that

lines.speaker: grumio
lines.text: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for: Take up my mistress gown to his masters use! O, fie, fie, fie!

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: [Aside]  Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid. Go take it hence be gone, and say no more.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Tailor, Ill pay thee for thy gown tomorrow: Take no unkindness of his hasty words: Away! I say commend me to thy master.
Exit Tailor

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Well, come, my Kate we will unto your fathers Even in these honest mean habiliments: Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor For tis the mind that makes the body rich And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, So honour peereth in the meanest habit. What is the jay more precious than the lark, Because his fathers are more beautiful Or is the adder better than the eel, Because his painted skin contents the eye O, no, good Kate neither art thou the worse For this poor furniture and mean array. if thou accountst it shame. lay it on me And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith, To feast and sport us at thy fathers house. Go, call my men, and let us straight to him And bring our horses unto Longlane end There will we mount, and thither walk on foot Lets see I think tis now some seven oclock, And well we may come there by dinnertime.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: I dare assure you, sir, tis almost two And twill be suppertime ere you come there.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: It shall be seven ere I go to horse: Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do, You are still crossing it. Sirs, lett alone: I will not go today and ere I do, It shall be what oclock I say it is.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: [Aside]  Why, so this gallant will command the sun.
Exeunt
